mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rattans (canes) in India. A Monographic Revision

nomenclature.name: Calamus acanthospathus
nomenclature.author: Griff.
nomenclature.bibref: Beccari, Ann. Roy. Bot. Gard. Calcutta 11 : 283. 1908, & Appendix Pl. 105. 1913.

treatment.div: A moderately robust rattan; stem cluster-forming, with leafsheath to 5 cm in diameter, without leafsheath 2 - 2.5 cm in diameter, smooth, green. Leaves ecirrate, about 1.5 m long; petiole insconpicuous, rachis with robust digitate claws on one side; leafsheath mostly covered with small tuberculate spines and broad-based, solitary, confluent spines; flagellum about 1.5 m long; leaflets to 45 cm long, 5 - 6 cm broad at middle, broadly lanceolate, many-nerved, inequidistant on rachis, not in groups or in pairs; terminal leaflets slightly connate at base. Inflorescence flagelliform; primary bract leathery, closely sheathing, smooth or more or less armed with short conic prickles. Male rachillae unknown. Female rachillae arching, sub-scorpioid, 5 - 6 cm long, with 10-14 flowers in each rachilla, arranged in unilateral series. Fruit broadly ovoid, suddenly beaked, 2.5 cm long, 1.5 cm broad at middle, dull orange in colour; fruit scales in 15 series, shining, superficially channelled at middle; seed deeply pitted on dorsal side; endosperm sub-ruminate; embryo basal.
INDIA (West Bengal, Sikkim, Meghayala, Assam, Arunachal Pradesh), BHUTAN.
A strong climber of the lower and middle hill forests of Eastern Himalaya up to 2000 m. In West Bengal and Sikkim it is frequent at the east of Tista river.
Experimental cultivation exists under D.F.O. North Silviculture, West Bengal.
Local people use the cane for making cane bridges over the mountain streams. Thinner canes are used for making baskets.

Assam : Lakhimpore, Dulong R.F. 21.11.1957, Panigrahi 11278 (CAL & ASSAM); Meghalaya : Garo Hills, 27.3. 1955, Kanjilal 5336 (CAL & ASSAM); Arunachal Pradesh: Abor Expdt. 5400-6200 ft. 31.1.1912; Burkhill 36542 (CAL); West Bengal : Baradabari, 27.4.1961, Indo-Russian Expedition No. 336 (CAL); Sikkim: Lower Chumbi, 6000-7000 ft Dec. 1904, Searight 72 (CAL).
